Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <FishyGuts> @bishop 
*miketout I have a ton of respect for you, I genuinely wish this gets resolved sooner rather than latter, but at this time, I cannot see how the gap can possibly be closed
the performance gap is just too out of reach*

Wasn't the same the case just recently.
When you make a cake, you break a few eggs.  
These eggs will get cooked into the recipie somehow and the coin will survive.
Hardware advancements are inevitable.   Lookup Moore's Law.  
The best that can be done long term is to look at fundamentals (and if you think a great coin like VERUS was just started because of an algorithm or to support miners incomes, then I have news for you). 
Features and methods change.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <FishyGuts> 100 years ago doctors gave you Cocaine and Morphine for a cold or flu.  Cars only functioned on gas.  Computers were not even a thought in anyones mind.

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Diabolik> @@miketout Which is the issue FPGA are causing, other than reduced (or none) profit for hobbyst? When you release something in the wild, you can't keep fighting for every thing doesn't align with the vision or you will get overwhelmed. I can understand the "decentralization vision" but, forcing someone to stop a behaviour isn't and probably Verus will be attacked for this. Assuming everybody in the world has the same hardware and can only mine the same amount, what if tomorrow arise a much more profitable coin and all miners switch to it? Imho, the mining should be considered a simple transport protocol (you can run a tor node or a wifi hotspot in your house for your pleasure but you are not paid for it) it cannot be "The big thing" or the core of a project. It may be a too ahead of times vision but totally aligned with today IT paradigms

I never seen someone scream at AMD, just example, because their new cpu is more powerful with less watts ðŸ˜ƒ 

@Gloryman Some (almost all tbh) people don't have the billions needed to run a datacenter, but everybody turn on VMs using Google, Azure, etc.... What's the point?
